item.title: Assad Arrives in Russia After Fleeing Syria, Russian Media Says
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad landed in Russia, according to state media outlets there and two Iranian officials, after fleeing the country as rebels took control of Syria’s capital.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times

item.title: Bashar al-Assad of Syria Falls to Rebels
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad had kept opposition forces at bay for a decade with help from Russia and Iran. But rebels struck at a moment of weakness for those countries.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A defaced banner showing President Bashar al-Assad on a street in Aleppo on Thursday. After a 13-year civil war, his government collapsed with surprising suddenness.

item.title: Records Seized by Israel Show Hamas Presence in U.N. Schools
item.description: While Israel asserts that the United Nations has tried to minimize the problem, the global organization says Israeli officials are waging an unfair campaign to discredit it.
item.dc:creator: Jo Becker and Adam Rasgon
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers standing next to an access point made by the Israeli military into a tunnel said to have been built by Hamas that ran beneath an UNRWA school, as photographed during an escorted tour in February.

item.title: 43,000 Ukrainian Soldiers Killed Since Russia Invaded, Zelensky Says
item.description: The tally differs sharply from estimates by U.S. officials and military analysts, who have said the number is closer to 70,000.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral last month for a Ukrainian soldier on the outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine. Ending the war was a major theme of a meeting on Saturday between President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President-elect Donald J. Trump.

item.title: With Assad’s Fall, Iran’s ‘Axis of Resistance’ Unravels
item.description: Tehran’s main regional allies are weakened or collapsing: Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, has fled his country, Hezbollah is battered by conflict with Israel, and Hamas is still at war.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard showing people holding photos of Ayatollah Khomeini, from the days of the Islamic revolution in Tehran, Iran, in November.

item.title: Notre-Dame Holds First Public Mass in Years: ‘Fire Has Not Conquered Stone’
item.description: Sunday was the first opportunity for worshipers to return to the cathedral, beloved by the faithful and secular alike, since the 2019 fire that devastated it.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Priests at the newly reopened Notre-Dame Cathedral after the Sunday evening service.

item.title: Ukraine’s Aggressive Draft Efforts Are Facing a Backlash
item.description: After being left for dead by Russian soldiers, Mykola Kulichenko doesn’t think he should be forced to serve. His experience highlights the vagaries of Ukraine’s aggressive mobilization.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: John Dramani Mahama Is Set to Return as Ghana’s President
item.description: John Dramani Mahama, who served as president from 2012 to 2017, is set to return to office after his main opponent, Mahamudu Bawumia, conceded defeat.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Olympia De Maismont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: John Dramani Mahama speaking during a rally for his party on Thursday in Accra, Ghana.

item.title: South Korea Unsure Who Is Running the Government
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ill-fated bid to impose martial law has created a power vacuum in his governing camp, pushing the country deeper into what analysts call a constitutional crisis.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol at a rally outside the National Assembly in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: She Sued Over Transgender ‘Conversion Therapy,’ a First for China
item.description: Ling’er won a settlement payout from the hospital where she was held for three months against her will and subjected to electroshock therapy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ling’er posing for a portrait in the room she recently rented in Tianjin, China, in November.

item.title: Syrians Mourn All They Have Lost, Even as They Celebrate
item.description: Thoughts of loved ones dead or missing complicate joyous relief at the prospect of Bashar al-Assad’s losing power.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
item.media:credit: Aref Tammawi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrians celebrating in the central city of Homs early on Sunday.

item.title: South Korean Leader’s Deal to Avoid Impeachment Signals Bigger Turmoil Ahead
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol survived an opposition-led attempt to remove him by getting his party members to back him. But his troubles could now become theirs too.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters demanded that President Yoon Suk Yeol step down and be arrested in a mass demonstration near the National Assembly in Seoul on Saturday.

item.title: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris Reopens: Photos
item.description: As Notre-Dame reopens after a 2019 fire, here is a selection of scenes from the famous Paris cathedral during a weekend of preparations and ceremonies.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris reopened this weekend, more than five years after a devastating fire.

item.title: South Korea Bars President From Traveling Abroad
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol cannot leave the country as an investigation unfolds into whether he led an insurrection last week when he briefly imposed martial law.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Yonhap/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea with Oh Dong-woon in May, when Mr. Oh was appointed as head of the office investigating high-ranking officials.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A historic transition of power in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Louai Beshara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A toppled statue of Syria’s late president, Hafez al-Assad, in Damascus yesterday.

item.title: Revolutions Swept the Middle East in 2011. Will Syria’s End Differently?
item.description: Bashar al-Assad’s downfall evokes memories of uprisings in Egypt, Libya, Tunisia and Yemen, each of which brought civil war or authoritarian rule. Syrians hope for better.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds celebrated the end of Bashar al-Assad’s long and brutal grip on Syria on Sunday on a road leading to the border between Lebanon and Syria.

item.title: Massacre in Haiti Ordered by Gang Leader Leaves Over 100 Dead, Rights Group Says
item.description: The killings in a Port-au-Prince slum, which appeared to target practitioners of voodoo, were ordered by a gang leader, a human rights organization said.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: An armored police vehicle in Cité Soleil, a slum in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, in May.

item.title: Trump Picks Former Ambassador to Mexico for Deputy Secretary of State
item.description: Christopher Landau is a longtime lawyer and the son of a veteran U.S. diplomat who served as ambassador to three nations in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Eduardo Verdugo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Christopher Landau in 2019. Because of his background in dealing with Mexico, Mr. Landau could be tasked with handling migration and tariffs in the Trump administration.

item.title: With Syria in Flux, Turkish Forces Attack U.S.-Backed Forces
item.description: Rebels supported by Turkish air power fired on a Kurdish-controlled city in northern Syria, pitting proxies of the U.S. and Turkey — NATO allies — against each other.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Delil Souleiman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Destroying a statue of Bassel al-Assad, the ousted president’s brother, on Sunday in Qamishli, Syria, on the border with Turkey.

item.title: Stunned Iranian Officials Try to Distance Their Country From Assad
item.description: A reckoning emerged in Iran on Sunday as officials and commentators swiftly moved to distance the government from a tyrant it had supported.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The damage after Syrians looted the Iranian Embassy in Damascus, Syria’s capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli Ground Forces Cross into Syria, Officials Say
item.description: Israeli ground forces have overtly crossed into Syrian territory for the first time since the 1973 October War, passing the demilitarized border zone, two Israeli officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Atef Safadi/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Israeli troops in the buffer zone with Syria, in the Golan Heights on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Al-Assad Flees Syria as Rebels Claim Power
item.description: Plus, Notre-Dame reopens.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds gathered near the Maasna border crossing into Syria.

item.title: Syria’s Army Was Hollowing Out Long Before Rebels’ Advance
item.description: While multiple factors contributed to the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, corrosion inside his own military did not help, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Ali Haj Suleiman/Getty Images
item.media:description: Abandoned tanks lined up at Mezzeh Air Base after Syrian forces deserted their posts on Sunday in Damascus.

item.title: The Assad Family’s Legacy Is One of Savage Oppression
item.description: A dynasty bombed and detained thousands of opponents, building fearsome internal security agencies to quash unrest.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: Portraits of Hafez al-Assad, left, and his son Bashar al-Assad, who succeeded him in power, at a hotel in Damascus.

item.title: Biden Weighs Approach to Rebels in Syria Amid Secret Message Exchange
item.description: President Biden faces the challenge of deciding how to engage the main armed group that toppled President Bashar al-Assad, even though it remains designated a terrorist organization by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Adam Entous
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Bonnie Cash for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re cleareyed about the fact that ISIS will try to take advantage of any vacuum to reestablish its capability,” President Biden said on Sunday.

item.title: Syrians in Lebanon Start to Head Home, With Both Joy and Worry
item.description: Thousands who fled during the country’s civil war celebrated the toppling of the Assad government — and their long-awaited return home — at the Syria-Lebanon border crossing.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: People waving flags celebrate in the street while stuck in the traffic jam leading up to the Lebanon-Syria Masna’a border crossing on Sunday.

item.title: What’s Next for Syria After the Collapse of Assad’s Government?
item.description: Predicting Syria’s future is challenging, as the government’s sudden demise took many people who have watched the region for years by surprise.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Syrian presidential palace in Damascus after President Bashar al-Assad was ousted.

item.title: Bogged Down in Ukraine, Russia Pays a Price in Syria
item.description: With the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Vladimir V. Putin has suffered one of the biggest geopolitical setbacks of his quarter-century in power.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Mohammed Al-Rifai/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A destroyed Syrian Army tank in a street in Hama, Syria, on Friday, a day after rebels captured the city.

item.title: Nations and Leaders React to Toppling of Syria Regime
item.description: The U.N. special envoy called it a “watershed moment” on Sunday as world leaders reckoned with the news.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Erdem Sahin/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Syrian opposition supporters at Fatih Mosque in Istanbul waved the opposition flag and celebrated the rebel takeover of Damascus on Sunday.

item.title: As Syrian Rebels Take Charge, Freeing Prisoners of Assad Is a Priority
item.description: Many people want to determine the fates of loved ones who disappeared into a notorious military prison that was a symbol of human rights abuses under President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Operations Room to Conquer Damascus, via Reuters

item.title: Biden and Family of Austin Tice, Who Is Missing in Syria, Say They Believe He Is Alive
item.description: President Biden said on Sunday that U.S. officials believe they can bring Mr. Tice home, but that they do not know where he is.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous
item.media:credit: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Debra Nice, center, the mother of the kidnapped journalist Austin Tice, asked Friday for help in locating him. The family believes he is still in Syria.

item.title: As Syrian Government Loses Control, the Skies Above Go Quiet
item.description: For years, people lived in terror of airstrikes by Syrian and Russian planes that helped keep the country’s authoritarian leader in power.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:credit: Aaref Watad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An aerial view of the Syrian central city of Homs on Sunday.

item.title: Who Is Abu Mohammad al-Jolani, Leader of Syrian Rebel Offensive?
item.description: Abu Mohammad al-Jolani spearheaded a lightning assault that led to the fall of President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Abu Mohammad al-Jolani, the leader of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, last year in the village of Besnaya, in Syria’s northwestern Idlib Province.

item.title: The U.S. Couple Donating to Notre-Dame Restoration Efforts
item.description: A couple from North Carolina are part of the second-largest group of donors to the huge fund-raising effort to restore the famous cathedral: Americans.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nick and Suzie Trivisonno, of Charlotte, N.C., donated to the Notre-Dame renovation efforts after the famous Paris cathedral was badly damaged in a fire in 2019.

item.title: Inside the Four-Day Workweek Experiment
item.description: A British group is pushing for more companies to offer their workers shorter hours. Here’s what it looks like for two companies willing to test it out.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Tom Jamieson For The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Kimber, a senior engineer at the software company BrandPipe, in his home office in East London last month. His company is testing a four-day workweek.

item.title: Israel Enters Golan Heights Buffer Zone After Syria’s Assad Falls
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said he had ordered troops to “take over” the zone between his country and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli tanks parked near the demilitarized buffer zone between Israel and Syria in the Golan Heights on Sunday.

item.title: South Korea’s Ex-Defense Chief Is Detained Over Martial Law Episode
item.description: Prosecutors are investigating whether President Yoon Suk Yeol and his followers committed insurrection when they briefly put South Korea under martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Yong-hyun in October. He was the South Korean defense minister until his resignation last week.

item.title: U.S. Spy Agencies Monitor Chemical Weapons Storage Sites, Fearing Use in Syria
item.description: But aides to President Biden have made clear that the United States has no intention of intervening in support of either President Bashar al-Assad or the rebels.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous
item.media:credit: Ghaith Alsayed/Associated Press
item.media:description: Syrian opposition fighters ride along the streets in the aftermath of their takeover of Hama, Syria, on Friday.

item.title: With Pageantry and Dignitaries, France Unveils a Reborn Notre-Dame
item.description: Five years after a ruinous fire, the reopening of the cathedral restored it in full glory to the Paris skyline and delivered a much-needed morale boost for France.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset, Catherine Porter and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reporters near Notre-Dame after the ceremony for its reopening.

item.title: Trump Attends Notre-Dame Ceremony in First Foreign Trip Since Election
item.description: At the ceremony, the president-elect took a seat next to President Emmanuel Macron of France, with whom he has had a rocky relationship.
item.dc:creator: Simon J. Levien
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump was in Paris on Saturday for the reopening of Notre-Dame Cathedral.

item.title: In Romanian Village, Anger Fuels Support for Ultranationalist ‘Messiah’
item.description: A presidential election has been called off, but the discontent that propelled the surging campaign of a rightist firebrand rages on.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Matei Barbulescu
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheep grazing in Pestera, Romania, on Saturday. Nearly half the villagers have moved abroad.

item.title: As Assad’s Regime in Syria Needs Help, Iran Exits
item.description: The collapse of a partnership built over four decades would reshape the balance of power in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Sam Hariri/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rebel fighters near a defaced portrait of President Bashar al-Assad in Daraa, Syria, on Saturday.

item.title: Zelensky Meets Trump in Paris to Press Ukraine’s Case
item.description: The Ukrainian leader planned to use the grand reopening of Notre-Dame Cathedral to lobby the president-elect and other world leaders attending the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France poses with President-elect Donald J. Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine ahead of a trilateral meeting at the Élysée Palace in Paris.

item.title: South Korean President Yoon Survives Impeachment Vote After Martial Law
item.description: The country was thrown into deeper uncertainty after the governing party changed its stance and refused to oust him. Protesters vowed to keep the pressure on.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters called for the impeachment of South Korea’s President Yoon Suk Yeol in Seoul on Saturday.

item.title: Notre-Dame Reopening Ceremony Attendees Include Trump, Prince William and More Officials
item.description: Dozens of officials have been invited to Paris as the rebuilt cathedral welcomes visitors five years after a devastating fire.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside Notre-Dame Cathedral the night before its reopening, on Friday.

item.title: Notre-Dame Cathedral Reopening Ceremony: How to Watch and Schedule
item.description: A speech by President Emmanuel Macron and a religious service will precede the broadcast of a taped concert by French and international musical artists.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Notre-Dame Cathedral is reflected in a café window in Paris.

item.title: Trump to Attend Notre-Dame Cathedral Reopening and Meet With Macron
item.description: The president-elect will be at the cathedral alongside dozens of world leaders. He was also meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France, with whom he has had a rocky relationship.
item.dc:creator: Simon J. Levien
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump was in Paris on Saturday for the reopening of Notre-Dame Cathedral.

item.title: Syria Civil War: What to Know About the Rebels and the Fall of Assad
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad fled the country as rebels claimed the capital, Damascus.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ghaith Alsayed/Associated Press
item.media:description: Syrian opposition fighters after the opposition’s takeover of Hama, Syria, on Friday.

item.title: Year in Review
item.description: As critics issue their year-end lists, we want to know your personal favorites of 2024.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s 988 Crisis Hotline, a ‘Pathway to Survival,’ One Year Later
item.description: The hotline responded to more than 300,000 calls and texts in its inaugural year, reinforcing appeals for Canada to establish a national suicide prevention strategy.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The use of a crisis hotline number as a song title by the rapper Logic was followed by a reduction in suicides in the United States.

item.title: Syria’s Government Battles Multiple Rebel Uprisings
item.description: The longtime Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad is facing threats from rebellions on numerous fronts as his key ally, Iran, is paring back support.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Bakr Al Kassem/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Anti-government fighters celebrating the capture of Hama, Syria, on Friday.

item.title: In Fight for Syria, a Battle for Domination of the Middle East
item.description: In a region “already on fire,” analysts say, rebels’ advance toward Damascus is a barometer of the shifting power dynamics that also affect nations like Iran, Turkey, Russia and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Muhammad Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrian antigovernment fighters pouring into the city of Hama on Friday.

item.title: In Congo, a Medical Mystery Offers Clues to the Mpox Epidemic
item.description: In a remote Congolese town, a medical mystery led to the discovery of alarming changes in the mpox virus and, eventually, to a global health emergency.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Moses Sawasawa
item.media:credit: Moses Sawasawa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yves Mujula, who works for Congo’s National Institute of Biomedical Research, and Serge Siklui, who works with the aid agency Alima, carry a cooler box of virus samples from a broken-down vehicle on the Kamituga road.

item.title: On These Apps, the Dark Promise of Mothers Sexually Abusing Children
item.description: Smartphone apps downloaded from Apple and Google can allow parents and other abusers to connect with pedophiles who pay to watch — and direct — criminal behavior.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Child safety advocates demonstrated at the Apple Store this month in New York’s Grand Central Terminal.

item.title: Protesters Vow to Keep Pressure on South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol
item.description: Demonstrations in the city and nationwide demanding the president’s ouster intensified through the week, and Saturday’s rally was the largest yet.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Brolley Genster
item.media:credit: Kim Soo-Hyeon/Reuters
item.media:description: Protesters taking part in a rally calling for the impeachment of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, near the National Assembly in Seoul, on Saturday.

item.title: Athens Revives Hadrian’s Aqueduct to Help With Water Crunch
item.description: Hadrian’s Aqueduct supplied water to Greece’s capital for centuries but was then largely abandoned. It’s being revived to ease water scarcity amid global warming.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: A section of Hadrian’s Aqueduct in Athens. Its 15-mile network runs beneath the city and is still functional.

item.title: Read President Yoon’s Speech Apologizing for Declaring Martial Law in South Korea
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol said his declaration of martial law was born out of “desperation,” and apologized for causing “anxiety.”
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Iran Begins to Evacuate Military Officials and Personnel From Syria
item.description: The withdrawals by one of President Bashar al-Assad’s key backers come amid a resurgent rebel offensive.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Bakr Al Kassem/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An antigovernment fighter covers his ears as a multi-barrel rocket launcher fires against government forces, in the northern outskirts of Syria’s west-central city of Hama on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Accelerates Production of Near-Bomb-Grade Uranium, IAEA Says
item.description: The United Nations chief inspector says production has quadrupled. But it is not clear whether Iran is trying to touch off a crisis or gather bargaining chips for negotiations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Abedin Taherkenareh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Rafael Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, with Abbas Araghchi, Iran’s foreign minister, in Tehran last month.

item.title: A Second Trump Term Is Set to Scramble Trade Alliances
item.description: Europe’s new pact with South America, its largest deal to date, could be a sign of how countries will diversify trade relationships as Donald Trump threatens tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Jorge Saenz
item.media:description: Barges used to transport soybeans in Paraguay, a member of the South American bloc that the European Union finalized a trade agreement with.
